3a8911b0-ad82-4231-9123-1108772b5b42.description: Skills: Communicate with patients, families, communities & professionals in health & other fields in a responsive, culturally-informed, & respectful manner. Use the knowledge of one's own role & those of others to effectively & compassionately address & assess the health & social care needs of patients/clients to promote & advance the health of populations. Apply relational & team-based values, principles, & skills to perform different roles.Maintain a climate of mutual respect & shared values.
3a8911b0-ad82-4231-9123-1108772b5b42.name: IP Honors

issuer.summary: issued by University of New England

badge_template_activities.title: Attend Four (4) CECE events, each mapped to one (1) of the IPEC collaborative competencies: Communication, Roles/Responsibilities, Teamwork, and Ethics/Values. Events are considered ‘exposure’ level experiences, and are open to all students. They often include an experiential opportunity for students to learn with, from and about each other while addressing a particular topic.
Reflective paper on CECE events attended – each reflection centered around an IPEC collaborative competency: Communication, Roles/Responsibilities, Teamwork, and Ethics/Values.

Participate in one (1) 'immersive', ‘interactive’, or 'competency level' event (team immersion; service learning; pre-clinical or clinical activity; simulation with required written or performed product). Must be approved in advance by CECE/faculty mentor.

Develop and present an interprofessional/collaborative team project (e.g. poster session; slide presentation; panel;
interactive session; formal presentation to audience). Must be approved by CECE/faculty mentor.
For additional information send an email to: CECE@une.edu

f4284563-bd6c-4bea-9c47-66d8d65d9c8d.description: An earner of this badge can: Articulate insight into their own cultural role, biases and worldview; Define intercultural experience from the perspectives of own and more than one worldview; Act in a supportive manner that recognizes feelings of another cultural group; Describe, distinguish and analyze how socially-constructed systems perpetuate cultural inequities; Formulate and utilize strategies for changing discriminatory, prejudicial, oppressive, and stereotypical attitudes or behavior.
f4284563-bd6c-4bea-9c47-66d8d65d9c8d.name: Diversity Leadership

issuer.summary: issued by University of New England

badge_template_activities.title: Participate in 4 Workshops:  Unconscious Bias,  Gender and Sexuality (LGBTQ+ Safe Space Program),  Race and Racism, Class and Classism

Participate in at least three approved events: At least 1 Social Justice (for example a Rally, Protest, City Hall meeting, Dr. MLK Celebration, etc.); At least 1 Service Learning Project (for example UNE Day of Service, volunteer at Food Bank, Boys and Girls Club, etc.); Attend at least 1 Spiritual place other than one you identify with (for example, a mosque, Pow Wow, Quaker service, Wiccan ceremony) Diversity Lecture Series, or other intercultural/diversity themed events

Write reflections on each workshop or event and submit a final reflection by completing prompts that demonstrate understanding of cultural humility, strategies for changing oppressive structures, and advocacy/allyship
For more information on acquiring this badge contact Andrea Paredes, Associate Director of Intercultural Student Engagement, aparedes2@une.edu.

2666cbd1-8a36-48b9-b162-60088d9fc18a.description: An earner of the Multimodal Literacy Badge will demonstrate basic competency in multiple modes of digital communication and reflective practice by: 1. completing three digital projects using basic audio, image and/or video editing skills; 2. appraising and analyzing the medium choice and its effectiveness for each project; 3. revising one project into a different medium or for a different audience. Projects and reflections are displayed in the student’s self-curated WordPress ePortfolio.
2666cbd1-8a36-48b9-b162-60088d9fc18a.name: Multimodal Literacy

issuer.summary: issued by University of New England

badge_template_activities.title: Create and Curate and individualized e-portfolio (Wordpress) site to document process as well as final product demonstration
Create three digital projects in at least two media forms. Each project must have a specified audience and purpose and should be edited to create a clear communication that utilizes the medium well
For more information contact: Michael Cripps, Director of Composition, English Dept., mcripps@une.edu or Jen Gennaco, DigiSpace Coordinator, jgennaco@une.edu

5caa1f59-2db3-44eb-bb2e-f6ab85906b93.description: Learners will increase their knowledge base and responsiveness to student trauma as a result of adverse childhood experiences. They will research the neuroscience behind trauma, learn to recognize signs of trauma in the classroom, analyze student behavior through a trauma-sensitive lens, evaluate the characteristics of a safe learning environment, design a self-care plan to combat secondary traumatic stress when working in a school-based setting, and present their findings in a final project.
5caa1f59-2db3-44eb-bb2e-f6ab85906b93.name: Trauma Informed School Practice

issuer.summary: issued by University of New England

badge_template_activities.title: Participants will engage in in individual and cohort based scholarship to answer the essential questions aligned to the competencies listed above.
Evaluate the characteristics of a safe learning environment by analyzing an approved program, considering academic, social, emotional, behavioral, and physical safety in the evaluation.

Earners create a plan for establishing a relationship-based approach to your school-based practice by meeting with their cohort to share approaches for relationship-based practices within the school setting
Meet with cohort to reflect upon ideas for and create a basic self-care plan to build resiliency to ensure effectiveness and presence in a school-based setting.
For additional information contact:  Krysten Gorrivan, Assistant Teaching Professor Education, kgorrivan@une.edu or Kris Winston, Associate Professor Occupational Therapy (OT), kwinston@une.edu.

661c226b-c1e8-43b1-b469-bb40cf7a58eb.description: Earners of this badge will be able to describe characteristics of multilingual leaners and principles of language development; describe teaching strategies and create a learning plan based on best instructional practices for multilingual learners; evaluate instruction through a series of case studies; and design a multilingual leaner tool kit to be shared with others in similar profession.
661c226b-c1e8-43b1-b469-bb40cf7a58eb.name: Supporting Multilingual Learners

issuer.summary: issued by University of New England

badge_template_activities.title: Describe characteristics of Multilingual Learners (ML) and principles of language development. The learning activities for this competency include: Review content related to getting to know Multilingual learners (readings, videos, images, audio) and review content to related to language development. (readings, videos, images, audio). Complete a Self-check and one activity from the Task Choice Board

Describe teaching techniques to Create a learning plan based on best instructional practices for Multilingual students. The learning activities for this competency include: 1) Review content related to instructional practices (readings, videos, images, audio). 2) Complete a Self-check. 3) Pick an ELL profile. Write a lesson/create a learning experience for that student. Final Assessment includes a lesson plan/learning experience around key features of learning

It is important that you can identify and evaluate effective instruction for multilingual learners. Learning activities for this competency: you will watch a video/s and use the evaluation sheet to analyze the instruction that you have observed.
It is important that you can take the information that you have learned and apply it to your context. For this assignment you will be asked to create a toolkit that you can use with your ML learners.
For more information contact Lane Clarke - lclarke@une.edu

022420f8-314e-4e1b-b46c-b37829865948.description: Earners of this badge will have demonstrated their ability to: engage stakeholders and build collaborative teams to further campus sustainability initiatives; solve complex problems by analyzing current practices, determining benefits of and barriers to sustainable alternatives; advocate for environmentally responsible practices by creating and communicating inspiring messages; and analyze and reflect on their own demonstration of sustainable choices and leadership impact on the UNE community.
022420f8-314e-4e1b-b46c-b37829865948.name: Sustainability Leadership

issuer.summary: issued by University of New England

badge_template_activities.title: Students will respond to prompts, facilitate meetings in the planning and reflection stages of stakeholder engagement opportunities where sustainability initiatives are discussed and decided.
Students complete the Environmental Council Project Initiation Form.
Students will initiate and participate in at least three approved communication activities that address chosen campus sustainability projects.
Students document their sustainability leadership journey in an ePortfolio.

9a52d1ed-1090-4aa7-937d-3baa09f675df.description: Earners learn basic animal husbandry and genotyping skills, which make them a valuable addition to any laboratory or facility using transgenic rodents in research. Mastery of relevant skills include proper handling and care of rodents, breeder establishment, animal identification, tissue collection, DNA extraction, PCR performance, gel electrophoresis, and the analysis of results they have compiled into a database from creating spreadsheets to labeling gel images.
9a52d1ed-1090-4aa7-937d-3baa09f675df.name: Genotyping Skills

issuer.summary: issued by University of New England

badge_template_activities.title: Students will be taught and required to demonstrate proper rodent behavior techniques. This will include basic restraint, sex identification, ear notching, and tissue collection by tail biopsy.

Earners will be taught, then required to demonstrate how to extract DNA from the collected samples and perform PCR. This will enable the student to identify the specific genes in question for each strain of mouse from which they collected tissue. They will also learn various breeding schemes and how to plan a transgenic colony. Throughout the process, students will have the opportunity to run protocols of increasing complexity, as well as learn basic PCR troubleshooting techniques.

All results, notations, and lessons will be recorded in a laboratory notebook. The notebook will provide proof of mastery, as will a student’s ability to conduct the process from beginning (tissue collection) to end (PCR analysis) on their own.
Pre-requisites: Student must complete CITI rodent laboratory training as well as UNE Brightspace laboratory safety training.
If you have questions, please email: behaviorcore@une.edu

63cbe7b2-c4cf-4b42-97ea-af0b4708c14a.description: Earners will learn the skills needed to perform basic rodent behavior techniques, making them a valuable asset in any pre-clinical research laboratory. Learned skills include: proper handling and care; restraint and systemic injections; maintaining an anesthetic level; blood collection and humane euthanasia. Once learned, the skills will be used in a student run experiment where we will cover, data input, basic graphing, statistical analysis and how to compile a final report.
63cbe7b2-c4cf-4b42-97ea-af0b4708c14a.name: Rodent Behavior Skills

issuer.summary: issued by University of New England

badge_template_activities.title: Students will be taught and required to demonstrate proper rodent behavior techniques. Once learned, they will conduct their own research experiment at the University of New England. Technique include: healthy observations & basic handling; restraint & systemic injections, maintaining an anesthetic level, blood collection and humane euthanasia.

The student will then set-up a basic study to assess locomotion in a rodent. Two different treatments will be administered and the amount of movement will be quantified. A 2-tailed t-test will be performed to determine if there is a significant difference between the treatment groups.
The skills learned and experimental results will be logically placed together into a power point presentation. This will serve as the final report and a way to express the data.
Pre-requisites:  Student must complete CITI rodent laboratory trainings as well as UNE Blackboard laboratory safety trainings.
If you are interested in this badge, sign up by completing this form.
If you have questions, please email:  behaviorcore@une.edu

d0828541-ccac-47d8-9122-97b3e3b78ebe.description: An earner of the Aquatic Food Production Badge is able to design and maintain both an aquaponics system and a recirculating aquaculture system and is capable of scaling each to meet capacity needs. This earner is able to apply aquaponics and recirculating aquaculture knowledge and critique to real world situations.
d0828541-ccac-47d8-9122-97b3e3b78ebe.name: Aquatic Food Production

issuer.summary: issued by University of New England

badge_template_activities.title: Complete workshops Aquaponics MAR 367 and Recirculating Aquaculture Systems MAR 370
Attend one of the two events: New England Farm to Institution Summit or Northeast Aquaculture Conference & Exposition

As an alternative to attending events, complete an internship at Bangs island Mussels, Ocean Approved Seaweed farm or Muscongus Bay Oyster Farm, or at another site determined in consultation with the badge issuer
For more details contact:  Jeri Fox, Associate Professor,  jfox@une.edu

820546c9-ad11-4a32-860f-f2bf11d3ad3c.description: Earners can: Demonstrate knowledge of and proficiency in search skills; Formulate a research question and craft and execute a research strategy; Critically appraise the authority of information creators while remaining skeptical of the systems that evaluated those authorities; Demonstrate proficiency in evaluation of resources used for research using the CRAAP (currency, relevance, accuracy, authority, and purpose) method; Contribute to scholarly conversation at the appropriate level.
820546c9-ad11-4a32-860f-f2bf11d3ad3c.name: Information Literacy I

issuer.summary: issued by University of New England

badge_template_activities.title: Earners write a reflection paper discussing research strategy and the learning involved in creating that strategy.
Students will incorporate the CRAAP method and write an annotated bibliography with focus on the annotations to determine student’s comprehension of resource evaluation.

For more information contact Sonya Durney,  sdurney@une.edu, Research and Teaching Librarian, Cadence Atchinson, catchinson@une.edu, Online Research and Teaching Librarian, or Bethany Kenyon, bkenyon@une.edu, Digital Access Librarian.

bcd82405-4083-49ff-946b-c318d8e68b22.description: Earners become proficient with state-of-the-art imaging instrumentation and techniques: transmitted light microscopy, widefield epifluorescence microscopy, confocal microscopy, image collection, and image analysis of biological samples. Proficiency will be demonstrated in a culminating product of the earner's accomplishments that would be integrated into a specific research project overseen by a UNE Principal Investigator, and feature a figure(s) suitable for publication.
bcd82405-4083-49ff-946b-c318d8e68b22.name: Microscopy & Digital Imaging

issuer.summary: issued by University of New England

badge_template_activities.title: Prepared biological samples will be analyzed by Transmitted Light Microscopy. Learner will be trained on the operation of the transmitted light microscope  Use Nikon e800 or Leica DM2500 to demonstrate brightfield, Keyence to demonstrate phase contrast. Earners will learn and operate to collect an image. Earners then demonstrate their skills, evaluate their progress and create a new product using refined techniques.

Prepared biological samples will be analyzed by Widefield Epifluorescence Microscopy. Learner will be trained on the operation of the widefield microscope using DM2500 and Olympus VS200 to demonstrate. Learner will learn and operate to collect an image. Earners then demonstrate their skills, evaluate their progress and create a new product using refined techniques.

Prepared biological samples will  be analyzed by Confocal Microscopy.  Learner will be trained on the operation of the confocal microscope  Use Leica TCS SP5 confocal to demonstrate principles and operation of LSCM. Student will learn and observe only, but images will be acquired. Earners then demonstrate their skills, evaluate their progress and create a new product using refined techniques.

Specialized software and images included in prior competencies will be analyzed using principles of Digital Image Analysis. Learner will collect digital images using an area detector (camera) and point detector (PMT) in the course of learning each microscopy technique. Learner will learn about fundamentals of digital image processing, extract data from an example image, and provide a written method for the analysis used.

1d912e70-c990-4ee1-94d1-b13d282bc94c.description: Earners become proficient with state-of-the-art histological instrumentation and techniques: principles of tissue fixation, paraffin or cryoembedding, paraffin or cryosectioning, histochemical staining principles and/or immunohistochemistry/immunofluorescence principles, and basic microscopy. The technical skills and product often are integrated into a specific research project overseen by a UNE Principal Investigator, and feature a figure(s) suitable for publication in a peer-reviewed journal.
1d912e70-c990-4ee1-94d1-b13d282bc94c.name: Principles of Histology

issuer.summary: issued by University of New England

badge_template_activities.title: Earners understand and apply techniques of fixation by preparing biological samples that are submerged in solutions containing fixative chemicals under defined conditions of temperature and duration for the purpose of preserving morphology and improving histological processing. Earners then demonstrate their skills, evaluate their progress and create a new product using refined techniques.

Earners understand and apply techniques of embedding, by  preparing are either a) dehydrated in alcohol gradient or b)  cryoprotected in  sucrose, then placed in molds containing either a) liquid paraffin or b) frozen sectioning compound (OCT), and oriented for optimal sectioning geometry.  Earners then demonstrate their skills, evaluate their progress and create a new product using refined techniques.

Earners understand and apply techniques of microtomy, by preparing samples within solidified paraffin OCT blocks that are sliced using a microtome or cryostat.  Sections are mounted on glass microscope slides  or placed into buffer for free-floating staining.  Earners then demonstrate their skills, evaluate their progress and create a new product using refined techniques.

Earners understand and apply techniques of staining, by preparing sample sections that are treated with a variety of solutions designed to enhance image contrast and/or detect specific features relevant to their scientific project, either by dye reactions or immunostaining.  Earners then demonstrate their skills, evaluate their progress and create a new product using refined techniques.
Earner will submit a final powerpoint presentation depicting the methodological  details and results of their technical applications using images and text.
